comment._content:
Nancy Bavin ? - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16721709
"Miss Nancy Bavin was in orange and white printed chiffon with a natural-toned baku hat. ... "
Whoever it is, she looks fabulous!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] This is not as clear as the others, if only they images were in colour! It does say she was in a 'printed chiffon' dress, and this one doesn't appear to be printed. We were thinking this one might be her: bit.ly/LDg8Nl
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Deetje Andriesse you look terrific. I googled the name to find several references in the fashion and social pages of 1930s Sydney. Somewhere out there there will be relatives and friends who will love to see this photo.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, there are rather a lot aren't there? If this is her, it is of special significance because it is such an early portrait. The other numerous (but poor quality) photos that appear in the society pages are from the mid-late 30's. I think these newspaper articles on Deetje Andriesse are of particular interest - In 1935 she was photographed by Harold Cazneaux. The photo appeared in the February issue of The Home magazine - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/55537947 In April 1937 she was photographed at work in her new studio in the Victoria Arcade (somebody tell agrippinamaior!). She had just returned from Europe, where she had studied leather-work for 2 years - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17363797 In 1938 Thea Proctor painted her portrait - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17538248, which was exhibited at the Macquarie Galleries in November - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17540382 Also, it would appear she immigrated to Australia in 1922 with her parents and a brother - mariners.records.nsw.gov.au/1922/09/032hou.htm

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] She does look lovely. She was known in Sydney's art circles, but as you say pellethepoet, there are no earlier images of her except this, which is not very clear: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16808372 This one, nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40994836, is clear, but it doesn't look much like her. The description we included above from the newspaper report of the JAVA event seems similar to this woman's clothing, however, it is difficult to say for sure that it is her.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks!!! That's a great link!

comment.author: 27686624@N07
comment._content: What is her face expressing? What is she looking at? Why is she holding a book in her hand at a party? Mysteries.....

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/8365984263/in/photostream/] the Home, 1 November, 1930, p. 52 I hate to be a damp squib to all the romantics, but her name is Doreen and she was born at Dubbo! ...or something like this... Per the Home this is Miss Hera Roberts (who was born at Dubbo in 1892). I've only just now come across this pic and conversation...there's a stack of info out there on Hera Roberts...plus a few pics which confirm that this young woman is indeed her...here's her brief DAAO entry www.daao.org.au/bio/hera-roberts/ ...I suspect this pic of Hera Roberts has been long forgotten...so it's bit of a find! Looking at the SLNSW cat it appears they might have some Cazneaux negatives of her... The NLA has this pic nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn3563348 Regardless, next time I'm in the library, I'll track down the issue of the Home which has the pics of Deetje Andriesse and post them just for interest...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Totes amazeballs ... ... !

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Miss Hera Roberts you look terrific.

comment.author: 92943860@N00
comment._content: excellent sleuthing...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Brilliant job quasymody and what a find! Thank you for that scan, I can see now that Hood's beautiful photographs were published. Thank you for solving the mystery, especially as I had serious doubts about my original guess. Great to see I got the other guesses correct though. Thank you again for sharing that scan, it would be great if you could share the others. Ironically, in my research I did come across the NLA pic when researching Charles and Hannah Lloyd Jones in this photograph, but of course had no way of knowing that Hera Roberts was really the one I should've been looking at. :) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] She certainly does!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/paleolit] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92943860@N00] To all those admiring the lovely Hera, see also George Lambert's beautiful portrait of her held at the National Gallery of Australia.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] thanks for the link to the George Lambert portrait. It's fantastic. My apologies for the lack of quality with these pics. The lighting wasn't ideal, I didn't have a tripod and I was operating under certain constraints (grumpy librarians, etc). I'm sure that a pro could produce much better results...plus photos of photos bring further issues re perspective into play. Regardless, these Cazneaux pics are really quite something...the one of Deetje Andriesse is stunning. If the original negatives could be tracked down, provided they were still in good condition, these would make wonderful prints. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/8379470006/in/photostream/] Hera Roberts, the Home, 1 March, 1927, p. 23 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02/8378391549/in/photostream] Deetje Andriesse, the Home, 1 February, 1935, p. 35

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Yes, the Lambert portrait (1924) is wonderful;  she seems to be echoing the pose in this photo six years later - left hand on hip, averted eyes, etc.

Great stuff!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Actually, it's held at the National Gallery of Victoria (www.ngv.vic.gov.au/col/work/5816). It was on exhibition at the NGA. I don't remember ever seeing it before. I'm sure I'd remember such a stunning portrait. Nice find.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Among Hera Roberts' many accomplishments (see the NGA blurb) was also acting, playing Lady Bracknell in "The Importance of Being Earnest" in 1925 !! - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16216152

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The problem with having a vast library is that one forgets one's books! Here's Ure Smith and Hera Roberts (in a book bought last year before Hera was identified ... and still unread) - Ure Smith, Hera Roberts, a friend, Hannah Lloyd Jones and Charles Lloyd Jones by Harold Cazneaux (undated, c.1935?) from Nancy D. H. Underhill, Making Australian Art 1916-49 : Sydney Ure Smith, Patron and Publisher (Melbourne : Oxford University Press, 1991), p. 54. And there's Hannah and Charles Lloyd Jones (see here & here) popping up again. Which begs the question ... was Ure Smith aboard too?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] It's the never ending story this one! ;) It's funny how when information comes to light, it opens a whole heap of other doors. Ure Smith wasn't reported to have been one of the guests. But then again, he already had his Home journal correspondent present to analyse the fashions :) Thanks so much for sharing that photograph!

Recreating the 1929 Hera Roberts Burdekin House room www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/channel/clip/481/ A look at how the Art Gallery recreated graphic artist Hera Roberts’ design for a room in Sydney’s now famous 1929 Burdekin House exhibition of modern interior design.
